B00000DCH9|5.0|Well this is certainly not Billy Joel's most commercially successful album, since even many people who claim to be Billy Joel fans have only heard one or two of the songs on it. However, it is my favorite recording of his hands down. Joel recorded it at a time when he was not locked into writing the somewhat uninspired pop-rock tunes you hear on the radio. This was the first rock album I ever bought, and I still enjoy listening to every song except the cheesy love song \\"You're My Home.\\" Of course, Billy's signature song \\"Piano Man\\" resides on track two, but it is hardly the focal point. \\"Travelin Prayer\\" is cool and has some great instrumental work, while \\"Ain't No Crime\\" manages to muster an impressive gospel blues sound from a band of mostly white guys. \\"The Ballad of Billy the Kid\\" is awesomely unique and innovative, and was the song that got me into rock and roll in the first place. \\"Worse Comes to Worst\\" isn't exactly a highlight but it has its moments, and \\"Stop in Nevada\\" is a nice lazy country tune with a good chorus. Joel does some nice vocal work on \\"If I Only Had the Words\\" even though the song is a little boring. I love \\"Somewhere Along the Line;\\" it has a gospel/country feel that really kicks it into gear and leads perfectly into the closer. Last is the greatest Billy Joel song of all, the deservedly infamous \\"Captain Jack.\\" This song contains some of Joel's most chillingly graphic and powerful lyrics, and some very haunting vocals as well. The chorus just rips right through you, especially at the end.
B00005JP8V|4.0|No one knows where the Power came from. In 1692, in the Massachusetts colony of Ipswich, five powerful families steeped in the dark arts form a covenant. One of the families, seeking to gain more power, is exiled. For hundreds of years, nary a trace was found of that banished family - until now. Cut to the present, where the focus is on the Sons of Ipswich, four teenage students, all around 16 and 17 years of age - Caleb, Reid, Tyler, and Pogue - attending the priveleged Spencer Academy.<br /><br />These kids, descendants of the magical families, are gifted with supernatural powers passed on by their ancestry. But the caveat is that the more the addictive powers are used, the more they prematurely age the user. And when they turn 18, they will \\"ascend,\\" thereby increasing their powers a thousandfold. In the past, the overriding temptation to use these powers have often proved to be irresistable to others, at the cost of their lives. Tonight, unbeknownst to the Sons of Ipswich, the bloodline of the long-vanished family returns.<br /><br />At the start of the new school year, an outdoor party is being held. The Sons of Ipswich show up, having dropped off from a cliff. There, they meet the acquaintances of newcomers Sarah Wendham (Laura Ramsey) and Chase Collins (Sebastian Stan), both of whom promptly ingratiate themselves into the group. Caleb Danvers (Steven Strait, from Sky High), the oldest and most level headed of the Ipswich group, and mere days away from his 18th birthday, falls for Sarah, who reciprocates the attraction, to the consternation of Reid, the youngest and most rebellious. Meanwhile, a triangle forms amongst Pogue, new kid Chase, and Pogue's girl and Sarah's roomie Kate (Jessica Lucas).<br /><br />The creepiness begins when that same party produces the dead body of a student, who seemingly died from a drug overdose. That night, Sarah gets the feeling she is being watched in the showers - and she's right. Meanwhile, Caleb suddenly wakes up, sensing that someone has used the Power. The next morning, he's driving his car when a darkling - a manifestation of the dead boy - suddenly appears in the passenger seat, startling the bejeezus out of Caleb and causing him to collide head on with a truck. But Caleb's got the Power, and he survives without a scratch. You've seen the trailer.<br /><br />These unsettling incidents are just harbingers of more sinister events in the offing. It quickly becomes evident to Caleb that a malignant, supernatural force is on the prowl. Related incidents soon give rise to suspicions and jealousies amongst the Sons of Ipswich, threatening to dissolve their close-knit group. In the end, Caleb must summon his powers, even if it prematurely kills him, to save all that he loves against a warlock a thousand times more powerful than he.<br /><br />The trailer doesn't quite lie; this is a fun popcorn flick. The Covenant is reminiscent of The Lost Boys and The Craft in its hip,  horror-laden, teenage sensibilities. However, it improves on those films in the CGI department. The Covenant boasts some pretty cool f/x sequences. While not as inventive as I had hoped, the film does come up with neat ways of showcasing the young warlocks' powers. I only wish that it had an R rating, instead of PG-13. I wanted even darker, more brooding, and more horrific scenes. But that's just the ghoul in me.<br /><br />Starring a bunch of unknown, beautiful kids - but kids that are up and coming - this is a rollicking entry in the action/horror genre. Steven Strait, Taylor Kitsch, and Sebastian Stan stand out, all bringing an earnest and focused screen presence to the flick. Stan, in particular, does his best to chew up the scenery while resembling Jason Priestley more than a bit. Laura Ramsey, well, she doesn't bring in the sexy as much as usher in the cute. The sexy label adheres better to her roommate Jessica Lucas, who is hot, while Steven Strait and Taylor Kitsch (Pogue) seem to have taken over the smouldering look department.<br /><br />No complaints about the production values. This is a good-looking film, saturated in dark, brooding colors and tones, while the bangin' hard rock soundtrack serves to drive the story and lends immediacy to the scenes. With fantastic visuals, a complement of well-meaning young actors, and an interesting supernatural premise, The Covenant also benefits with the insertion of certain themes cloaked under the guise of fantasy horror - notably, the themes of addiction and that sense of immortality and invincibility that you feel when you are young.<br /><br />I quite liked this movie so I hesitate to state the negatives, but you gotta be honest, right? So, here goes. The movie would've been greatly served with a tighter script (how many times have we seen the female lead tell the hero, \\"I'm scared\\" and the hero respond with a \\"Don't be\\"?). There are parts in the middle that seemed to plod and drag on for too long. Like I said before, maybe an R rating would have improved the film, made it more scary. And there isn't enough jeopardy. Maybe, you'll disagree, but I felt there weren't enough victims, leaving the stakes not as high as they should've been. The ending seems a bit rushed and feels abrupt. Frankly, I expected more from the showdown between Caleb and the exiled descendant of Ipswich (by the way, I feel like a numbnut not saying the person's name; it's stupendously obvious, as the film doesn't even really try to camouflage the baddie's identity). And the other Sons of Ipswich could've been showcased more (Tyler was basically non-existent). Anyway, by the end, I didn't get the sense that everything had been resolved. Maybe the powers that be are thinking sequel? I wouldn't mind.<br /><br />Anyway, it's not a great film, merely a decent one, but one which I do recommend. I say it's around three and a half stars. So, what else is there to say? If you have some time to kill, you could do worse than watch this film. Hope this helps make up your mind.ook department.<br /><br />No complaints about the production values. This is a good-looking film, saturated in dark, brooding colors and tones, while the bangin' hard rock soundtrack serves to drive the story and lends immediacy to the scenes. 015626224X|5.0|Having read only one of George Orwell's books (\\"1984\\") when I was younger, I'm rediscovering him now, having recently read \\"Animal Farm\\" and \\"Down and Out in Paris and London.\\"  Down and Out is a fascinating account of life as a hotel-restaurant worker in the early 2oth century in Paris and London. It's a very graphic account of what is was like to work up to 18 hours a day in brutal conditions and still be poor and hungry. It's also amazing to see the differences between being poor in France and being poor in England. Although I'm no Francophile, it certainly was easier to be poor in France.<br /><br />Orwell is a great writer, and it really shows in Down and Out in Paris and London. His characters are finely drawn, and the reader can almost feel the sweltering heat, the impossible working conditions, and the hunger of an empty belly.<br /><br />I was amazed at the conditions of the poor in England and the system that almost guaranteed that they remained in poverty. France wasn't a lot better, but at least it was a bit easier to be poor in that country.<br /><br />A fascinating look at life in another era.
B000FOQ1EA|5.0|This is a superb set of the Sibelius symphonies, one of the finest I've heard. Blomstedt, famous for his two cycles of Nielsen symphonies, knows the style and character of this music as well as anyone. There is an intensity and seriousness here that suits the music well. The playing of the San Francisco Symphony is excellent throughout, especially the brass. <br />The first two symphonies receive bracing performances that balance the structure with the content of the music very well. The Third ranks with Davis and Jarvi as one of the best on record. The Fourth is a fine performance that captures the brooding atmosphere of the piece, though the finale (with tubular bells) doesn't find the balance of darkness and light that I had hoped. <br />The Fifth is spectacularly good, with tempi and dynamics judged to perfection. The Sixth is rather strange. Consistently slow, it meanders dreamily and misses the joy of the piece. Blomstedt is back on form for the Seventh, which is rugged and positive, making a fitting climax to an altogether wonderful set.

B0007XT87G|5.0|Just brief history of this prog fan, I differed from my peers as a kid growing up in the 60's I liked the non-commercial contempory artists, spending hours under the bed cloths listening to the likes of Captain Beef Heart on radio Luxenberg, being blown away by Page,Clapton, Genesis, Yes, to name a few artist's that my hard earn't paper run money helped fund!! Well I found the same excitment all over again with Deadwing, listening to samples on the prog rock archeives to begin with, simply curious about an unusual name. I was just as stunned as when I was a child in the 60's again! The track \\"arriving somewhere but not here\\", sounds as classic and iconic as the best from all those previously mentioned artists, it brought back memories of the pleasure of discovering \\"wish you were hear\\" \\"Lamb lies down on Broadway\\" Led Zep 4 etc. The music could best be described as similar to Pink Floyd, perhaps less commercial, and with no known boring tracks. I found the clean licks of Steve Wilsons guitar very similar to David Gilmour, and the quiet understated vocals with simple harmonys intoxicating. There could be similarities to Steve Hillage, though the songs are very current and will have a more modern atmosphere, also I felt that the music was very carefully crafted with slightly ambiguous lurics that I love, giving an overall impression of being incredibly well produced and engineered. Gavin Harrisons drumming is a revelation in its self, complicated, meticulous and above all interesting. The bass guitar of Colin Edwin providing additional melody lines, rather than just filling out the sound with depth and rhythm complementing the other musicians beautifully. The atmospheric keyboard work of Richard Barbieri I think lends a huge hand in giving the music such a strong colour and vitality, with captivating intensity and charisma. This was the first Porcupine tree CD I bought and it is now one of my favourites of all time, I am learning more and more new things so it seems every time I hear it. I have heard critism that is less favourable than some of the earlier CDs, but I would have to say this Band is heading in a great direction and manage to change and do something different, as in true progressive music. Yes Porcupine Tree are hard to catagorise, they are obviously on a journey which I will follow with great interest, and am trying to drum up interest down here in this part of the world, but if you want to succeed in New Zealand or that little place next door you will have to tour!!! (Please) GO BUY THIS CD!!!!!
B000FP2OPY|4.0|REVISED FOR BLU-RAY RELEASE:<br /><br />THE ORGININAL DVD RELEASE:<br /><br />The best horror show since \\"The X-Files\\" is a witty, clever series which will keep you glued to your seat. Dean and Sam Winchester hunt monsters. After the death of their mother at the hands of a mysterious poltergeist like spirit their father begins a life long obsession with hunting down and destroying the creature that killed his wife. He also hunts other creatures that prey on humanity. When he disappears his son Dean (Jenson Ackles)recruits his brother Sam (Jared Padalecki)to help find their father. In the process they end up hunting supernatural creatures along the way kicking their butts.<br /><br />The actors have terrific on-screen chemistry. I wondered how the show could come up with fresh material given that this show was preceded by the 70's series \\"Kolchak\\" (and before that the superior TV movies), \\"The X-Files\\" and \\"Night Stalker\\" but the producers and writers always manage to come up with fresh angles for the episodes. The show does have occasional cursing (for those that have small kids) and might be too scary for some kids but it's a great show to watch for everyone else.<br /><br />The DVD looks terrific with extras such as commentary (on the pilot and one other episode) as well as deleted scenes and behind-the-scenes featurettes about the actors and the production of the show. Some stores feature additional extras for example Best Buy has an exclusive disc focusing on \\"Supernatural at The Museum of Television & Radio Paley Television Fesvital\\" where the stars, creator/writer Eric Kripke and producers Kim Manners & John Shiban (\\"The X-Files\\") (as well as other producers on the show)discuss the creation, evolution and production of the series. They also answer those burning questions for fans...like why all the 70's rock music (AC/DC and others are featured in the show).  They also discuss the inspiration for the show (\\"The X-Files\\" among them not surprisingly) and changes that occurred from the pitch to production. Don't forget to take a look at the DVD-ROM features which allows you to visit a secret website, see a video of creator Eric Kripke discussing the first draft of the pilot script and where you read/print up the pilot script as well. You can also gain access to the car (and the trunk using a combination code as well for all the weapons beneath the cover).<br /><br />FOR THE BLU-RAY:<br /><br />The Blu-ray has two features that weren't on the original regular DVD edition. The \\"Supernatural at the Museum of Television and Radio\\" featurette has been added to ALL Blu-ray editions (it wasn't only available on certain DVD editions). There's also a \\"Roadmap\\" that takes you to all the of the locations for the first season episodes providing you with information on the legends.<br /><br />Image quality for the Blu-ray is quite strong with nice detail and a sharper more vibrant picture. For the money, it's a good upgrade or first time investment if you haven't seen the show in HD. Be aware that the show is deliberately grainy looking which is the style that the producers chose for the show. Also, the washed out colors of the show in this presentation is characteristic of the series and a stylistic choice.<br /><br />Regardless of whether you purchase the show on DVD or Blu-ray, \\"Supernatural\\" is an entertaining horror series and it wasn't until about 1/3 of the way through the season when the writers/producers retooled the structure of the show to focus much more on the characters. Creator Eric Kripke realized that the stars of the show had unqiue and strong on screen chemistry which made their performances as brothers believable. As the series progresses you'll notice sometimes that the creatures themselves (outside of the teasers) sometimes don't appear until midway thorugh an episode. Recommended.o production. The \\"Supernatural at the Museum of Television and Radio\\" featurette has been added to ALL Blu-ray editions (it wasn't only available on certain DVD editions). There's also a \\"Roadmap\\" that takes you to all the of the locations for the first season episodes providing you with information on the legends.    Image quality for the Blu-ray is quite strong with nice detail and a sharper more vibrant picture. For the money, it's a good upgrade or first time investment if you haven't seen the show in HD. Be aware that the show is deliberately grainy looking which is the style that the producers chose for the show. Also, the washed out colors of the show in this presentation is characteristic of the series and a stylistic choice.    Regardless of whether you purchase the show on DVD or Blu-ray, \\"Supernatural\\" is an entertaining horror series and it wasn't until about 1/3 of the way through the season when the writers/producers retooled the structure of the show to focus much more on the characters. Creator Eric Kripke realized that the stars of the show had unqiue and strong on screen chemistry which made their performances as brothers believable. As the series progresses you'll notice sometimes that the creatures themselves (outside of the teasers) sometimes don't appear until midway thorugh an episode. Recommended.

B000002KHH|5.0|Don't believe anyone who tells you that this album is overrated.  Black Sabbath are considered the founding fathers of heavy metal for a reason.  The truth is, no other band was writing anything this heavy back in 1971.  Led Zeppelin are a better band (in my opinion) and definitely influenced heavy music more as a whole, but Tony Iommi's style of riffing, and the band's gloomy, slow and relatively straightfoward style inspired legions of fans and musicians.  Just because there are better albums out there (which there are) doesn't mean that Paranoid isn't a five-star, undisputed classic album well worthy of the recognition it deserves. <br /> <br />Aside from its influence and popularity, Paranoid is a solid album from start to finish.  While being a little on the short side, (42 minutes) it still packs a mighty punch.  Every song here is well-written and strong, with the most popular songs being on the same level as the rest of the album.   <br /> <br />The band sounds very tight, and are able to play together as a single unit.  They jammed together extensively, (which resulted in the basic ideas for most songs on this album) and this gave them practice building off of eachother and shaping powerful, effective songs filled with solos and flair.  Guitarist Tony Iommi and drummer Bill Ward shine most of all, with Tony's charismatic soloing and crushing riffs, and Ward's rhythmic fills and accents.  Of course, Ozzy's voice was as it's most exquisitely whiny and screechy at this point in their career.   <br /> <br />War Pigs - An awesome, powerful opening song.  It's long, filled with both repetition and variation, which combine to make it a memorable, effective song that goes down in history as one of Sabbath's finest.  The lyrics are also very vivid and evocative. <br /> <br />Paranoid - The shortest, most immediate track on the album.  It's catchy and features great instrumentation.  There's nothing to complain about in this song, and it makes up one of the album's most publically popular tracks. <br /> <br />Planet Caravan - A slow, mystical sort of track, with distorted vocal mumblings by Ozzy and improvisational guitar work by Iommi.  A nice segway piece to bring the album into Iron Man. <br /> <br />Iron Man - This is the band's most well-known song of all time, due in large part to its infectious, simple-yet-heavy main riff and melody.  However, aside from its hype and popularity, it's also a well-crafted song in its own right, with all the elements that made War Pigs so successful.  Tony Iommi's melodic, harmonic and rhythmic sense is excellent, as he is the band's main soloist, as well as the backbone for much of the rhythm.  The song has a doomy, infectious quality about it which is irresistible.  It was this song (and others in the same vein) which helped craft the sub-genre of heavy metal known as doom metal--music centralized around a gloomy, almost impossibly slow pulse which packed a mighty punch despite not being as fast or poppy as other rock and roll.  Tony Iommi changes riffs at the drop of a hat, yet still manages to sound fluid...it's a rare and inspiring talent. <br /> <br />Electric Funeral - The songs starts out with an eerie, slow guitar riff reminiscent of Iron Man's.  In comes Ozzy's cynical vocal performance and the song is underway.  In some ways, the song plays off like a lesser Iron Man, but is still appealing in its own right.  As usual, the band changes time signatures and tones several times over the course of the song, inevitably returning to the riff the started it all.  Of all the songs on the album, this is the one which is most likely to get annoying--not a weak track per se, but weaker than others on the album. <br /> <br />Hand of Doom - The song starts out slow and builds to a soaring climax.  It's impossible not to love Bill Ward's rapid-fire, off-beat drum fills in this hallucinogenic drug song.  One of the album's highlights. <br /> <br />Rat Salad - This is a short instrumental track,which, aside from some call riffing and meandered soloing by Iommi, is made up almost entirely of drum soloing and fills.  It's a progressive, jammy song that shows off the band's virtuosity (especially Bill Ward, who is a very competent rock drummer).  It's blusey, improvisational sound reminds me a bit of early Yes or early Santana.  The album wouldn't be the same without this piece. <br /> <br />Fairies Wear Boots - This could be the album's most fluid, cohesive song.  It features the anxious drumming, powerhouse riffage, and strange lyrics which have become Ozzy-era Sabbath's trademarks.  This is probably the bluesiest song on the album, with Ozzy delivering a vocal performance slightly different to others on Paranoid.  The song is a perfect shocase for the band's ability to jam, change tones and rhythms like an attention-deficit-disordered child, and cycle everything back to a central theme.  It's an expertly crafted song, even if the main chorus and tone isn't as bleak or apocalyptic as Iron Man, War Pigs or Hand of Doom. <br /> <br />Overall, a stellar album by a talented band who got just a little bit worse with each release following this one  <br />(with a few exceptions).  Their first six albums are all high quality, but things get a little rough after that.  Kinda like Van Halen.   <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

B00005JP81|5.0|Ryan Fleck's \\"Half Nelson\\" is a film that stands staunchly for the principles of civilization and political empowerment, even as it demonstrates in microcosm just how compromised those principles can become. It is a film that never tells you what to think about the story or the characters, while at the same time demanding that you DO think about them, deeply. This alone is audacious for any American film. The superb, slice-of-life screenplay by Fleck and editor/producer Anna Boden presents Dan Dunne (Ryan Gosling), a history teacher in an inner-city middle school who tries to fill his mostly apathetic students with the leftist zeal he learned from his parents. Unfortunately, Dunne is the living embodiment of the old saying, \\"The spirit is willing but the flesh is weak.\\" His life is sliding downhill, thanks to a raging crack habit.  Nevertheless, he manages to keep his addiction out of the classroom until the day that Drey (Shareeka Epps), his brightest and most admiring pupil, catches him hiding in a toilet stall with his crack pipe. Drey is already an embattled soul; her brother is in jail for drug dealing, and Frank (Anthony Mackie), the neighborhood kingpin, is supporting Drey's family in exchange for her brother taking the fall for him. But this support has strings attached; Frank expects Drey to come into business with him. The brilliance of \\"Half Nelson\\" is in depicting Dunne and Frank's battle for Drey's soul, as Dunne slowly but surely loses whatever moral authority he possesses. Frank, the representative of urban decay and criminal evil, is a stronger personality than Dunne, and outwardly a more stand-up guy. (The big confrontation scene between the two is deeply sad and ironic.) The story plays out in ways that are fresh and surprising, yet always completely logical given the characters, and the end, though not the gift-wrapped resolution American audiences expect, offers a fragile ray of hope for both Dunne and Drey. A large part of the film's impact comes from the performances of the ensemble cast,which could not possibly be more natural, real, or compelling. Gosling, in particular, nails the contradictions of his character's personality, making the dichotomy between his idealism and his moral turpitude all too believable. Andrij Parekh's jittery, documentary-style camera adds to the you-are-there reality of the film. \\"Half Nelson\\" is not an easy movie, or one to see in an escapist mood. However, it is one that grows in your mind, becoming increasingly impressive as you think about it.s from the performances of the ensemble cast,which could not possibly be more natural, real, or compelling. Gosling, in particular, nails the contradictions of his character's personality, making the dichotomy between his idealism and his moral turpitude all too believable. Andrij Parekh's jittery, documentary-style camera adds to the you-are-there reality of the film. \\"Half Nelson\\" is not an easy movie, or one to see in an escapist mood. However, it is one that grows in your mind, becoming increasingly impressive as you think about it.

B000ETQRCM|5.0|It would be wrong to say that this marks a return to the days of Ten and Vs. for Pearl Jam. The style of this new, extraordinary album is by no means similar to those classics, but instead, it presents a new style and unfamiliar sound that is equally engaging. It does not reflect the same influences as their more experimental and less mainstream period either, although it seems to draw inspiration from both.  <br /> <br />The self-titled Pearl Jam follows the mold of a classic punk rock album, but one can still sense that there is an evident progression from the anger and darkness of Vs. to the more reflective and comtemplative themes of the self-titled. While Ten and Vs. seemed to be crying out with rage, Pearl Jam has faced a life wasted at this point. A major difference between this album and some of the previous ones is the driving guitar that had occasionally been lacking is back in a big way. Songs like \\"World Wide Suicide\\" and \\"Life Wasted\\" jog the memory of old Pearl Jam classics, but still present a new feel.  <br /> <br />Yet the album is preciously balanced between solid rock songs and slower, more comtemplative tracks. \\"Unemployable\\" is a personal favorite, as it explores the hardships of a life at the mercy of others. And this in itself is truly a reflection of why Pearl Jam is one of the greatest rock bands of their time; their music, whether heavy, soft, mainstream, or experimental, has never been self-indulgent and continues to intrest, insight, and inspire listener. As Eddie Vedder shamelessly admits on \\"Umemployable\\", \\"I've seen the light.\\" Well, so have I.
B000G759LW|3.0|I have to give credit to pop princess Christina Aguilera for the audacious career move she has made in releasing a two-disc set full of such relatively eclectic music at a time when the music industry is turning its back on the format. True, she is vocally more talented than Britney, Jessica and the rest of her helium-filled sorority, but she isn't as versatile as she or her handlers would want us to believe. That's not to say she will not achieve that level someday, but at the ripe old age of 25, Aguilera lacks the interpretative skills of any of the veteran singers she is trying to mimic here from Lady Day and Aretha down to Whitney and Mariah. She is still a singer who feels more comfortable showing off her gymnastic melisma than a sense of nuance and maturity.<br /><br />The first disc, however, is a solid showcase for her very specific talent thanks to the street-savvy production work of Gang Starr's DJ Premier. By far, the best song on the whole set is the highly charged lead-off single, \\"Ain't No Other Man\\", with its James Brown-inspired horn riffs, girl-group sass and the most infectious hooks of the summer. It sounds like prime Whitney with a welcome gutsy edge. \\"Makes Me Wanna Pray\\" is a sturdy soul shouter for Aguilera, benefiting from Steve Winwood's familiar Farisa organ which makes the song sound like a Spencer Davis Group outtake. The fifties-style doo-wop of \\"Understand\\" (with a great sampling of soul diva Betty Harris), the loping Quincy Jones-style of \\"F.U.S.S.\\", and the breezy, Stevie Wonder-lite \\"Without You\\" are all catchy in their radio-friendly ways. The disc unfortunately ends with too much self-aggrandizement with her overly defensive \\"Here to Stay\\" and her blowing air-kisses to fans on the egotistical \\"Thank You\\".<br /><br />While the first disc benefits from its relative consistency, the second disc suffers from its abundance of pretension. Produced by Linda Perry, Aguilera's songwriting partner on \\"Beautiful\\", it starts with an overly moody Cirque de Soleil-style downer, \\"Enter the Circus\\"; rebounds somewhat with the power ballad \\"Welcome\\" but then gets stuck in WWII-era pastiche with Aguilera's Andrews Sisters impersonation on \\"Candyman\\", a note-for-note rip-off of \\"Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy of Company B\\". The chanteuse cheekiness on \\"Nasty Naughty Boy\\" works for the most part, but the muffled scratchiness of \\"I Got Trouble\\" doesn't really help her get closer to the hard-earned melancholy of Bessie Smith. Self-indulgence is a major problem throughout as she seems to be channeling Streisand on \\"Hurt\\", Billie Holiday on \\"Mercy on Me\\" and an unlikely combination of Blossom Dearie and Fiona Apple on \\"Save Me from Myself\\". The last track, \\"The Right Man\\", is one melodramatic wedding song, but she actually handles it with aplomb.<br /><br />It's a bold experiment for Aguilera that shows off her burgeoning talent, but it's premature for her to tackle the variety of vocal stylings she tries to display here. If she waited a decade or just released the first disc by itself (without the last two tracks), I think she would have come across as far more impressive and far less precocious.eil-style downer, \\"Enter the Circus\\"; rebounds somewhat with the power ballad \\"Welcome\\" but then gets stuck in WWII-era pastiche with Aguilera's Andrews Sisters impersonation on \\"Candyman\\", a note-for-note rip-off of \\"Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy of Company B\\". The chanteuse cheekiness on \\"Nasty Naughty Boy\\" works for the most part, but the muffled scratchiness of \\"I Got Trouble\\" doesn't really help her get closer to the hard-earned melancholy of Bessie Smith. Self-indulgence is a major problem throughout as she seems to be channeling Streisand on \\"Hurt\\", Billie Holiday on \\"Mercy on Me\\" and an unlikely combination of Blossom Dearie and Fiona Apple on \\"Save Me from Myself\\". The last track, \\"The Right Man\\", is one melodramatic wedding song, but she actually handles it with aplomb.    It's a bold experiment for Aguilera that shows off her burgeoning talent, but it's premature for her to tackle the variety of vocal stylings she tries to display here. If she waited a decade or just released the first disc by itself (without the last two tracks), I think she would have come across as far more impressive and far less precocious.

B000051YEG|5.0|Serge Gainsbourg, will (in most peoples eyes), be the dirty little Frenchman, that seduced English rose \\"Jane Birkin\\", and mostly recorded his sleazy endeavour on the \\"Je T'Aime...Moi Non Plus\\" track.  But dig past those initial reservations, and you'll find that he was a composer of some seriously good Cabaret / French Pop / White-funk /  Jazz-Pop /  Baroque-pop, and although his music reminded something of a cult concern, his music generally deserved a much wider audience.  And with this album (considered to be his strongest album), he somehow nailed a consistency throughout the record, that his other records, weren't quite able to match. (admittedly it only contains 7 tracks), but contained here, are some of Serge's strongest compositions.  For further evidence of this, investigate the staggeringly beautiful 7 minutes that make up \\"Melody\\", a track that brings together sharp string sections, coupled with tightly rhythmic guitar, and a decidedly carefree (almost organically French) sound, that is more the music to a wonderfully moody Cinematic film, than anything to do with flimsy euro-pop, and such is the brilliance of this track, that \\"David Holmes\\" would go on to cover this track, for his \\"Lets Get Killed\\" album (The track is renamed \\"Don't die Just yet\\"), which is a virtual replica of Serge's version (save for small snatches of drum beats added to the mix, and a slightly more prominent string arrangement).  And almost as if to prove that this was no one off idea, he brings out the seriously funk-driven groove of \\"En Melody\\", a track that seemingly has Serge comprising a track that is unquestionably acomplished stab at white-funk, and it's a staggeringly brilliant effort, that if it wasn't for the cheeky passionate organism sounds peppered through the latter half of the album, most people would have been perfectly within reason to think that this was the work of some obscure, incredibly talented black, funk band.  And the remaining tracks \\"Ballade de Melody Nelson\\",  \\"Valse de Melody\\",  \\"Ah! Melody\\", \\"L' Hotel Paticulier\\" & \\"Cargo Culte\\" all flit between a sublime blend of kitsch and gimmick-esque tunes, yet remain outrageously brilliant, intoxicating amalgams of jazz and pop styles, that not only tackle bohemian jazz to rock and even synth funk with a style and eccentric wit, that become a calling card of Serge's music, and possibly one of the biggest reasons for his appeal. <br /> <br />This album is arguably the most consistent and cohesive of Serge's albums, and although running at a fairly brief 27 minutes, it's a fascinating record, one that is by turns funky, humorous, Hedonistic and Sensual, and has a such a tongue in cheek, carefree swagger about it, that you can't fail by be impressed by the sheer audacity of it all.  Those that had (like me) only really know Serge's work via his hit single \\"Je T'Aime...Moi Non Plus\\", would do well to give this a whirl.  It really highlights how overlooked his work really was, and that most people initially had him pegged as a dirty old Frenchman, who got lucky with a saucy single.  It's shamelessly overblown, impossibly cheeky, beautifully arranged, and impeccably performed...and most importantly it's a lot of fun to listen to.  Those buyers looking for the hits (or the nearest his songs became to be popular), would be well advised seeking out one of the many compilations bearing his name, but those that are interested in hearing what the pinnacle of his work sounded like, simply must check out this funky little gem.  Recommended!!! <br />
B000GIWS7E|4.0|If you're a DT fan, buy this. You won't regret it. <br /> <br />Overall, I love this DVD and I'm glad I bought it, but if I had to make one complaint... <br /> <br />Oh, I should also add that I'm only referring to the PCM stero version since I don't have a 5.1 surround setup. <br /> <br />As is often the case with previous DT releases (I&W and SFAM, most infamously), poor Johnny Myung's wonderful bass is lost in the mix. This is most notable on the first track, The Root of All Evil, where I could barely hear it at all and initially thought there was something wrong with my subwoofer. From then on the bass gets better, but compared to the way it was captured on Live at Budokan, its rather muddy and rumbly, instead of thick and deep as it should sound. <br /> <br />Other than my complaint about the bass, the quality of Score's PCM stereo mix is a vast improvement on Budokan's. John P's guitar is nice and loud here, despite what some other reviews may say about not being able to hear him. In fact, the PCM mix as a whole is nice and loud, again, as opposed to Budokan. Oh, yeah, the Orchestra, they are captured well too, but DT is given more presence when they are playing together, and thankfully, and wisely, the orchestra comes in only when needed...they don't just try to underscore every note. Another great thing about this mix is that there's no buzz-killing dynamic range compression like there was on Budokan: there's nothing more upsetting than expecting the song to get lounder at a certain point and instead hearing it get quieter. This time around, when the whole band kicks in, it gets louder! And when its supposed to be a quieter part of the song, it gets softer. <br /> <br />Oh, also, also also... James Labrie doesn't suck on this one!!! Those of you who have heard enough live DT recordings know that JLB kinda sucks live...or so we thought. Not only is he not straining or sounding winded while singing, but he's actually doing a good job. He sounds more in controlof his voice and he's hitting all the right (read: challenging) notes. And yes, he even belts that scream at the end of Octavariam, which is a truly spine-tingling moment (I wanted to cry and say 'You did it James! B000001E18|4.0|U2's 'Zooropa' is a bit of a let-down after their magnificent 'Achtung Baby'.  It is a brave, new effort that goes into more of a \\"space age\\" feel, adding to the technology of its predecessor.  The subject matter is more bleak, not unlike a series of depressed creations by \\"Major Tom\\".  It seems to look at the state of affairs, like usual; only this time Bosnia and technology seem to have staved off the party atmosphere of 'Achtung...'.  Significantly, that one was done after the fall of the Berlin Wall.  'Zooropa' soberly assesses the world after communism's collapse. <br /> <br />The title track is the most space age song they've done.  The lyrics evoke alienation in the starkest form.  If \\"Zoo Station\\" was the \\"Magical Mystery Tour\\" of U2's career, then this is the \\"Space Oddity\\".  \\"Numb\\" furthers the alienation with an industrial mix and the Edge's monotone rap delivery.  \\"Lemon\\" seems to disco-tize the music, making it sound like a space station lounge.  The lyrics reek of despair, but also contain hope with lines such as \\"Midnight is where the day begins\\".  (Perhaps mixing their senses like English poet, John Keats, they liltingly give mantras to stave off the desperation of \\"holding onto heaven too tight.\\"  They also seem to draw from Dante where the pilgrim and Virgil reach their destination out of hell at midnight, making Purgatory, a place and time.)  Melancholy fills the air with the aching longing of the love song \\"Stay (Faraway So Close!)\\".  With the Edge's simple, British invasion guitar licks and Bono singing lines like \\"Dressed up like a car crash/ Your wheels are turning, but you're upside down.\\"  It is also a serenade that would go well with a movie like \\"Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind\\" with lines like \\"Stay!  With the demons you drown...Stay!  With the spirit I've found...\\"  If the first half seems bleak, then the second half goes to further depths.  \\"Daddy's Gonna Pay for Your Crashed Car\\" takes a sublime and desperate look at the contingencies of life.  \\"Some Days Are Better Than Others\\" is sarcastic, but entertaining in its acceptance that some things just happen in life.  Both \\"Babyface\\" and \\"Some Days..\\" are upbeat,  yet contain able phrasing for such mundane subject matter.  They also reflect their desperate moments, not as poignantly as on 'The Joshua Tree,' but the despair reaped on \\"The First Time\\" and \\"Dirty Day\\" are almost frightening.  If the loneliness and desperation weren't enough, U2 finishes the album with Johnny Cash, singing ably a science fiction nightmare with \\"The Wanderer\\".  It is a vision of love gone wrong in a landscape of nuclear and environmental proportions.   <br /> <br />Perhaps 'Zooropa' alienated some fans.  It is not a happy sojourn after the brilliant 'Achtung...,' but it is a brave, unflinching ensemble that can help people work through depression and their worst fears of the future.  'Zooropa' was a bleak, but brave step for U2.

B000HBK3MM|4.0|Soul music is probably the easiest sound to replicate.  Every genre from country, to hip-hop, to jazz, to blues can pull elements of soul into it.  That's probably why it's the hardest category to break when it comes to success on the chart.  Usually it's the artists that get down deep into their own souls who have the most success when it comes to album sales.  Think about it.  The best albums from your favorite soul artists are usually the ones that you can either relate to yourself or that you felt was their most compelling when it came to stories they told.  Both of those things bring out the true essence of soul music.  That's probably why Corinne Bailey Rae has gotten so much buzz as of late because you can put on her self-titled album and your almost instantaneously engulfed in her world.<br /><br />\\"Like A Star\\" is a great choice to start off the album with considering the uncomplicated lyrics and the tranquility that she shows on the song.  It leads right into the serene nature of \\"Enchantment\\" but then she changes gears with the self-liberating debut single \\"Put Your Records On.\\"  \\"Til It Happens To You\\" will remind you of the bluesy sound of a Norah Jones, along with the moody \\"Trouble Sleeping.\\"  \\"Call Me When You Get This\\" is a ambient yet funky groove that is worthy of being another radio single.  Corinne belts out a couple heartfelt ballads over the smooth tune \\"Choux Pastry Heart\\" and the harmonious track \\"Breathless.\\"  She closes out the album with the upbeat, jazz-inspired \\"I'd Like To,\\" the heartening nature of \\"Butterfly\\" and the leisurely mood of \\"Seasons Change.\\"<br /><br />Although the album only clocks in at just over 45 minutes, Corinne gives you more than enough to enjoy.  It remains to be seen if the world will truly embrace Corinne Bailey Rae, but after one listen you'll agree that she is definitely a force to be reckoned with.  Do yourself a favor and grab Corinne Bailey Rae for a truly organic experience.

B00005JMEW|5.0|There was a time when science-fiction was considered mere pulp trash. It didn't matter to the kids back then--they loved it. They snuck their comics under the covers at night with a flashlight and played hookey in order to see the latest serial at the cinema. When they grew up, they wanted to bring that childhood love of theirs to the big screen, with one change: they wanted their movies to be respected. <br /> <br />And so, we have Star Wars, and the modern Battlestar Galactica and Firefly/Serenity. Sci-fi isn't mere pulp, anymore (if ever it truly was), no matter what the older generations might continue to feel. <br /> <br />Tarantino's plan is roughly the same, though his role-models are different. He's a fan of the action-packed 70s flicks. Kill Bill, vol. 1, is his ode to Kung Fu extravaganzas, with one change: respectability. <br /> <br />It's not a very complicated plot. Uma Thurman (\\"the Bride\\") was beaten into a coma on her wedding day, and now looks for revenge against those what done the beating (and especially their leader, Bill). The movie is about her gaining that revenge, usually through long and gory fight sequences. <br /> <br />Tarantino earns the respect he craves for his Martial Arts movie by 1) having quality actors fulfill the roles, 2) an awesome score, featured prominently (par for Tarantino's course) and 3) a variety of interesting and always changing visual and narrative styles. He shifts from black and white to color to animated sequences to flashbacks and back again. Neither the camera angles nor the kill-shots (and there are a bunch!) are ever duplicated. Everyone is provocatively dressed and distinctive, each sequence has its own feel, pacing and rhythm. A two-hour long Kung Fu movie with non-stop action could become boring. Tarantino never allows it. <br /> <br />That is his genius. <br /> <br />It turns out that every genre of film can be \\"good art.\\" I'm not sure whether Kill Bill would be the first \\"artistic\\" martial arts movie, orif it even matters. What matters to me is that this movie is a lot of fun--gruesome, violent fun. A striking film that students of cinema, and fans of old-time karate action alike, must see.

Not only all that, the band was cashing checks from major record companies that signed 'em and dumped 'em seemingly overnight.<br /><br />And through all the controversy came the U.S. album release. The power of the band - driven by the vocals of Johnny Lydon - is captured in classics like Anarchy in the UK, God Save the Queen and No Feelings. There were questions on who performed on the album, with persistent rumors that guitarist Chris Spedding played on most of the cuts.<br /><br />While the album received either rave or poor reviews by the critics, a U.S. tour was in the works, with one published report stating the Pistols were going to perform at Madison Square Garden with tickets costing a couple of bucks. Like so much surrounding the band, the MSG show was 99.9% myth.<br /><br />The Pistols were slated to debut in the U.S. with a performance on Saturday Night Live and then open their tour at The Agora in Cleveland, OH. B0002TKFRM|5.0|What a treat for the ears! <br /> <br />The Living Stereo series was wonderful then and it's even better now. This hybrid SACD has fantastic sound quality and, thankfully, is completely true to both music and the original recording. Originally recorded in \\"3 channel stereo\\" that's what you get here--no, there's nothing in the rear channels of the surround mix but that's exactly the way it should be. Taken directly from the nearly 50-year old (!) masters, the engineers did nothing at all to the sound except digitize and transfer each track to the SACD/CD master. Nothing added, nothing subtracted. And the quality of those masters is astounding--clear, bright and full. No tape hiss. No loss of highs. Just wonderful music expertly performed. <br /> <br />Dissapointed you're only getting 3 channels and not 5-7? Don't be. You'll hear the musicians arranged across the broad, but shallow, Chicago Symphony Hall just as the engineers heard them in the recording sessions in 1957. And those musicians are superb, particularly to my ears, the brass and woodwinds. This is an excellent orchestra caught at its prime. <br /> <br />In short, get this CD! Even if you don't have a universal player now, the 2 channel transfer is equally good, a faithful recreation of a classic LP. And if you can play the SACD layer so much the better because for the first time you'll hear exactly what was recorded and what the engineers heard in nearly 50 years ago.
B000AP04EW|5.0|How on earth can anybody watch this amazing, thoughtful, subtle, moving, sexy, challenging, disturbing movie and not love it for evermore? Reading some of the other amazon reviews makes me wonder whether the reviewers saw the same movie, or if perhaps they were too tired, or jaded by life, to appreciate it.  <br /> <br />Director Doug Liman and his two astonishing stars (plus a fantastic supporting task including the laconic but always watchable Vince Vaughn and the extraordinarily beautiful Michelle Monaghan in a great cameo as Gwen the laptop pathologist) have created one of the finest movies I have ever seen.  <br /> <br />The point about 'Mr and Mrs Smith' is that it really makes you think. Yes, when maybe you first see it you imagine you are just seeing another good action movie with some dollops of sex appeal thrown in. But PLEASE, remember that the people who worked on this movie spent hundreds of man (and woman)-years making it for you, so watch it again. I GUARANTEE you will start to see new, very brilliant and highly entertaining stuff in it. Like, to take just one example, the way the Smiths put their wedding rings back on when they return to the house, as if their secret lives were a kind of infidelity, which of course they are. Like the way what is REALLY happening in the film is that the violence and bad guys etc are just a wonderful and dramatic metaphor for the private, closedness that so many couples (or maybe all of us?) bring to marriages and relationships and which are utterly bound to kill the relationship stone dead. This is a movie about a couple who fall in love with each other's bodies and then, accidentally, really get to know each other and at last fall in love for real. The fact that to do this they have, in effect, to destroy their house, their careers and - almost - each other is really by the by.  <br /> <br />The movie is also astonishingly sexy. This is where you will find real sexiness; in this movie, not in nonsensicial porn movieswith no plots and bored, unjoyous actors and actresses. 'Mr and Mr Smith' is incredibly sexy because the sexiness is brainy sexiness: the kind that is the sexiest of all. Quite apart from the fact that the stars are filmed really well by this highly talented director (note, for example, the sheer beauty of the way Jane is lit when we first meet her in action in Bogota) the situations themselves have a fantastic inherent sexiness. For instance, the scene where Jane kills the arms dealer who thinks she is just a dominatrix is very sexy because of how it dramatises the strange deadliness of female sexuality: didn't someone (Rudyard Kipling, I think) say that the female is deadlier than the male? This scene would have stunned Kipling but it proves his point. And then Jane goes home in her fishnet stockings to a nice bourgeois all-American drinks party at the Colemans: notice the way this scene suggests the implicit wilful sexual energy and potency that underpins superficially bourgeois family life.  <br /> <br />I could go on, but I don't want to give away anything crucial about the plot. All I will say is that this movie really, really repays repeated viewings. I have seen it maybe a dozen times and stll find new things I love about it.  <br /> <br />Do yourself a favour: watch 'Mr and Mrs Smith.' And if you have watched it once, watch it again, and again. <br />
B0006PV5VC|5.0|What a treat for the ears! <br /> <br />The Living Stereo series was wonderful then and it's even better now. This hybrid SACD has fantastic sound quality and, thankfully, is completely true to both music and the original recording. Originally recorded in \\"3 channel stereo\\" that's what you get here--no, there's nothing in the rear channels of the surround mix but that's exactly the way it should be. Taken directly from the nearly 50-year old (!) masters, the engineers did nothing at all to the sound except digitize and transfer each track to the SACD/CD master. Nothing added, nothing subtracted. And the quality of those masters is astounding--clear, bright and full. No tape hiss. No loss of highs. Just wonderful music expertly performed. <br /> <br />Dissapointed you're only getting 3 channels and not 5-7? Don't be. You'll hear musicians across the broad but shallow Chicago Symphony Hall just as the engineers heard them in the recording sessions in 1960 and 1956. And those musicians are superb, particularly to my ears, on the Sheherazade portion. This is an excellent orchestra caught at its prime resulting in a truly world-class performance of this well known and well loved music. <br /> <br />In short, get this CD! Even if you don't have a universal player now, the 2 channel transfer is equally good, a faithful recreation of a classic LP. And if you can play the SACD layer so much the better because for the first time you'll hear exactly what was recorded and what the engineers heard in nearly 50 years ago.

It was a timely read for me!    I thought that I knew this story, but the years had passed and my memory was not as vivid as I had thought.  The story was as fresh to me as a new novel. This is the adventure of young Jim Hawkins who was lucky or unlucky enough to have found himself in possession of a map to Treasure Island. Jim is filled with curiosity and adventure as he sails forth on the ship, the Hispaniola.  Jim's friends who are sponsoring the voyage are Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey.   Notable crewmembers are Captain Smollett, a no nonsense and very capable seaman. and Long John Silver, a charming, but very cunning man who was hired as the ship's cook. Silver's companion is a parrot that he calls Cap'n Flint.     The excitement and danger of pirates, the lust for buried treasure and a mutiny aboard ship makes for an exciting book.  TREASURE ISLAND continues to be a great story for any child or adult who savors adventure.
B0000076BX|1.0|You'd have to be really deaf to like this album. Instead of epic rockers like The Score or The Miracle, you get trite bulls**t like Black Moon and Paper Blood. Instead of fun songs like Step Aside, you get embarassing songs like Better Days. Greg Lake's decline in singing ability is the most compelling anti-smoking argument I've ever heard. <br />Do yourself a favour and save your money. Seriously. Just say no to Black Moon.

B00004XONN|4.0|Radiohead started the new millenium with this, a fractured twitchy record, that is frighteningly alien (with a post apocalyptic chill) but at the same time warm and tender. <br />The album art says it all, showing a bleached barren landscape overrun with strange \\"evil teddy bears\\". It is Radiohead's definitive artistic statement, self consciously arty and esoteric, but at the same time it was where their sound was headed all along.  <br />Opening with the pulsing keyboards of \\"Everything In Its Right Place\\" and ending (after several minutes of silence) with a soundscape of bell like sounds, which builds from what sounds like hundreds of whispering voices (and then more silence). Kid A is an arresting listen, it demands that you hear the whole thing from start to finish. And it's very easy to want to do so.  <br />Some would find it too shocking, indeed, it has been described as nightmarish. But underneath everything the songs are still pure in their intent, and if one concentrates on them, they can create their own story from it. The lyrics are full of confusion, loneliness, anger, and defiance, something Radiohead are known for. The guitars may be gone but Radiohead are still there.  <br />Sonically, the album relies largely on repetition, particularly the bassline of the terrific \\"The National Anthem\\" and the beats scattered throughout the album are something to marvel at, sparse and metallic, but oh so listenable. The album also takes in styles not covered before by Radiohead such as electronic music in \\"Ideoteque\\", an abstract and very thin (and also the most vocal centred song on the album) ode to what seems to be human sin and ignorance. <br />Kid A is a hard record to love, but a rewarding experience is one can find the way in. It is a transcendant piece of music that should not be taken lightly.
6304479689|4.0|There is a very good reason for this film not living up to That the Way It Is.  I am sure if you have seen this movie you have noticed that it is much more grainey and not as bright as TTWIS or other movies for that matter. This contributes a lot to the picture not being as well received.  The fact of the matter is that MGM in it's infinite wisdom chose to shoot the movie in 16 mm not 35 mm as most all movies.  This is a little known fact.  But all you have to do is watch for many of the stage segments and you can see the photographers crawling around the various stages with a relatively small camera in hand.  They may have done this for maneuverability sake but with significant loss in quality.  16 mm is a long way from 35 mm in all measuring points.  This may also be why they have not put it out on DVD as yet.  The movie is very grainy and this adds a subconscious negativity to the movie.  I was present at many of the concerts that were filmed for this movie.  The live shows were not grainy at all and they were very sharp and well lit and came across much better than the film. <br /> <br />Content of a movie is always affected by how it is presented.  Long live the King

0440419514|5.0|I cannot paraphrase the story in any way that would do it justice. Pullman is beyond me; the story was too rich, too powerful, too complex and subtle and ambitious, and it had to be to be equal to what I now sit here wishing I could convey to you. <br /> <br />You must read it, and if you have read it already, then perhaps together, here and now, we can experience words, and maybe even create a bit of Dust. <br /> <br />The most inspired time of my life, as I remember, was during my tour of Europe three summers ago. I remember pieces of what I felt; the richness of human creation surrounding me, not just when I was among the amazing architecture of so many ages, but also when I gazed at the endless miles of soft, rolling hills in Switzerland, Austria, Holland, immaculately tilled and maintained. Something was so compelling; it shook me violently for many days, although my body never moved, but a crucial part of me was indeed shaking. Thoughts poured into my mind, making me on several occasions dizzy and alive at the same time, and at one point, when I thought I couldn't handle the strange consciousness anymore, I sat down, and out of what seemed to be frantic desperation I began writing a letter to a certain Stanford professor who did not know me, whom I had never talked to, but whom I had heard much about. <br /> <br />I wrote nearly a page, but it wasn't nearly finished, and I never did finish it; time passed too quickly, and my mind didn't stay in that amazing and different and wonderful grace for long enough. But since that summer, I named it aesthetics; I had discovered it sometime during freshman year, and that was when I started calling it aesthetics, but it had never shook me so violently for so long of continuous time until that summer. <br /> <br />And these days, just when I thought I have lost all but hope that I can relive and re-understand what I had known, I read Pullman's tale, and it was absolutely spot-on. <br /> <br />When I finished the last bookon the train, my mind drifted into an open calm for a long time, and there it rediscovered what it had known and had forgotten, but has always known. Pullman calls it intention, and I had called it aesthetics, but I think they really mean the same thing, both unequivocally human and unequivocally conscious. Pullman gave intention, or aesthetics, the form of Dust, and he made Dust beautiful, and in that open calm I remembered that I have always known Dust and that it has always been beautiful, and vast and the most meaningful thing there is. <br /> <br />It wraps around us, glowing, whenever we write or speak or engage with another; whenever we feel, empathize, or understand; or whenever we instill our intentions (or aesthetics) in anything we make or design or build or hope for. I think every person will experience it in his own way, and some level of his consciousness will know what I mean, because Dust is just the beauty of our assertive wakefulness, of our open minds, our thirst to learn and to create. It is unfortunate that we do not have a name for it, a single word in which one listen would allow us to experience the thousand page story of Pullman's tale, in an instant. <br /> <br />And lastly, a final thought occurred to me as I walked home from the train stop. I think when someone is sad or depressed, when someone has a sickness of the spirit, maybe the best medicine for him would be simply to learn something new about the world. To be inspired again. Because I think that is what we have been made for.

B000E33VWW|4.0|Phillip Seymour Hoffman disappears so totally into the role of Truman Capote that you forget you are watching a characterization.  \\"Capote\\" is the story of the writer's efforts to chronicle the saga of two killers who murder a prominent small-town Kansas farming family after burglarizing their home in a futile search for money.  On assignment for the New Yorker magazine, Capote is accompanied by childhood friend Harper Lee, who serves as an effective buffer between Capote's effete sophistication (which many find distasteful) and the staid conservatism of 1960's Middle America. Most strikingly, \\"Capote\\" portrays the mammoth moral struggle of the writer, who was at once calculating, coldly manipulative and then deeply sympathetic about the plight of the two killers, one of whom he befriends and gradually coaxes to tell his story.  The tremendous fame and wealth from the resulting book \\"In Cold Blood\\" did little to offset the enormous emotional and psychological cost of writing it.  Indeed, the film strongly suggests that Capote made a (faustian) bargain with the devil and never really recovered, finally succumbing to alcholism in 1984.  The great supporting cast includes Clifton Collins, Jr.--who personifies small-time desperation as one of the surprisingly articulate killers and Catherine Keener, who simmers as Capote's stoic, long-suffering friend, sidekick and unintentional rival Harper Lee, who herself becomes nearly as famous as Capote for a time after penning \\"To Kill a Mockingbird.\\"  \\"Capote\\" is a serious study--definitely not a \\"family film.\\"  Director Bennett Miller's brief but arresting images of the violence (murder, execution) prick the heart. Hoffman, who was one of the best things in the 1999 psychological thriller \\"The Talented Mr. Ripley\\" (in which he portrayed a loyal, suspicious friend whose skepticism proves fatal) gives one of the most powerful performances in recent memory--it's a masterful tribute to one of the most brilliantly tragic figures inAmerican literary history.

B000AP2ZDK|5.0|This album is a compilation of beats by a currently deceased hip-hop hero. Most of this album was made on a hospital bed; he struggled with lupus, an immune system disease. He was diagnosed with the disease a few years before the release of Donuts, but his dedication to making music was indelible. He even toured Europe in 2005 in a wheelchair. From a man who was dedicated to music his whole life, and even into his death, what kind of album do you think that man would make if he knew it was to be the last of his albums released during his lifetime? Released on his 32nd birthday, three days before his grievous death, Donuts is that album folks. Spanning 31 tracks, most of the songs last from 60 to 90 seconds. The album changes quickly, delivering many different flavors from the one and only J Dilla. <br /> <br />It's hard to rate each song individually, every one of them is so different from another that you will like some more than others, and maybe some not at all. Don't be too intimidated by the extensive amount of tracks the album, since they all go by really quickly; if you don't like one, the next is soon to come. Every track is very polished and refined, however, and Jay Dee certainly gave us an album that would have us miss him even more. If you are unfamiliar with Jay Dee, this album is the easiest and best way to get into his work. A genius comparable to Charlie Parker, as said by The Roots' ?uestlove, J Dilla has forever changed the standards of hip-hop production, and Donuts is the best example of his ability to create memorable music.

B00009W0U4|3.0|Why did so many people have trouble following this movie? Once you realize that the scenes are in reverse order -- which should become apparent early in the film -- the narrative is quite simple. And this is actually one of the film's weaknesses.<br /><br />In \\"Memento,\\" for example, the labyrinthine reversed narrative continually forces the viewer to reinterpret everything seen earlier (later) in the movie. \\"5x2\\" provides increasing psychological depth and poignance as the story of the two lovers moves towards its conclusion (beginning). But with \\"Irreversible,\\" it's just ... well, backwards. The relatively peaceful scenes following the rape are, for the most part, tedious and dull and overlong. The big \\"surprise\\" near the end is a wet firecracker compared to several of the powerful scenes in the first part of the film.<br /><br />It is these earlier scenes from which \\"Irreversible\\" has surely gained its accolades, and much of this praise is well deserved. Both the rape and (especially) the attack with the fire extinguisher are truly horrifying -- and that's a good thing. Rarely has the repellence of brutal acts like these been caught so vividly on film.<br /><br />The spinning, meandering camerawork and monotonous thudding soundtrack are less successful, however. The techniques themselves are interesting and effective at first, but the viewer's initial sense of disorientation and unease soon turns to simple irritation as the sight and sound gimmicks overstay their welcome.<br /><br />\\"Irreversible\\" contains a number of powerful scenes and is well worth seeing for those who can stomach the violence. Just don't come in expecting a brilliant narrative, depth of characterization, or psychological complexity.

B0001CVAME|5.0|I am generally apprehensive regarding remakes because they are often inferior to the original. I avoided this movie in the theaters for that reason. Eventually we got the DVD and I gritted my teeth to watch. To my surprise the remake covers new territory in switch films and was quite enjoyable.<br /><br />As with the original, the interplay is between mother Tess Coleman (Jamie Lee Curtis) and Annabell Coleman (Lindsay Lohan). However, in the original the daughter, played by Jodi Foster, was the stronger of the two roles and the mother just didn't quite spark my interest after the switch. In this movie both characters play well and Jamie Lee Curtis proves once again what a great actress she is.<br /><br />The best part of the movie is that the update is very modern. Annabell is faced with motorcycle riding hunks, is a member of a hard rock group, and wants to get more piercings. The character of Annabell is wonderfully rebellious yet not completely out of control.<br /><br />As with many teens, Annabell and her mother are arguing about something constantly. With a bit of Asian magic, and a rather tricky fortune cookie, mother and daughter switch bodies. The switch itself is hilarious. One of the scenes played in advertisements continuously is when Annabell, now in Tess' body, looks in the mirror and says that she's the Crypt Keeper. Jamie Lee Curtis is perfectly believable after the transition.<br /><br />We soon find that each really struggles with the other's world. Annabell can't keep up with all her mother's cell phones, PDA, and beeper. Further, driving seems to be quite a challenge for her. Tess discovers that her daughter was telling the truth about the English teacher who is continually out to get her, regardless of how well she does. It turns out that the English teacher and Tess know each other. Tess solves Annabell's problem quite nicely. However, Tess still has other problems, particularly with Annabell's friends. The peak of Tess' problems are during a rock audition that is very important to Annabell.<br /><br />There are additional conflicts for the pair to add even more spice. Tess is preparing to get married to Ryan (Mark Harmon), who is trying to understand his soon-to-be-daughter but, as with many fathers, is more than a little clueless. Annabell also has a younger brother that she sees as a pest. The switch allows candid conversations between Annabell and Ryan and Annabell and younger brother Harry (Ryan Malgarini) where Annabell learns that Ryan doesn't want to upset her life and truly wants to understand her and Harry loves her and admires her. The poignant moments are handled quite well with minimal schmaltz.<br /><br />The true point of the movie is for each to walk in the other's shoes. In the process of doing so we get to see some well done physical and situational comedy, most particularly by Jamie Lee Curtis. Both Tess and Annabell are both empathetic characters. While the focus is on the ladies, making this a mother-daughter film, males will enjoy the generational myopia of mother and daughter. A wonderful family film that I consider suitable for most family members.uring a rock audition that is very important to Annabell. <br /> <br />There are additional conflicts for the pair to add even more spice. From the very first seconds of \\"Aces High\\" I was floored. Sadly, I don't think Maiden will ever do that again.

0684800713|5.0|Hemingway came to his style of prose by writing the truest sentences he knew.  He says so in \\"A Moveable Feast,\\" his memoir of the Paris years when he was writing this, his first novel, but it also can be felt.  The sentences in \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" don't read as programmatic or mannered; they read as fresh, vivid, and clean, as if each had its own brimming source.   <br />  <br />Don't envy Hemingway that he was the first to write like Hemingway.  The way he wrote was by working damned hard, harder than most writers have ever worked.  He thought through each sentence as a thought as well as a sentence, and this is no easy task, and yields no easy formula.  Hence the newness and subtlety, and the sense that \\"The Sun Also Rises,\\" though full of frivolous characters, is sturdy and never frivolous.  It is unified by a sort of analytic integrity, and it needed a man with both feet on the ground to lend it weight. <br /> <br />The plot of \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" seems to make much of nothing.  Food is talked about, drinks are drunk, and young people do a lot of not thinking.  Jake, the American narrator, lives in Paris and travels to Spain to fish and watch bullfights.  His principle companions are a preppy leech and a weak flirt.  He's in love with the girl.  And yet the story doesn't meander because it isn't distracted by the allure of the inessential.  Go elsewhere to feel lost in France or Spain.  Hemingway was interested in making, not describing--in building art through language like Cezanne built images in paint: with deep structure trumping impressionistic reportage.  Like a Cezanne canvas, \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" seems drained of anecdote but never mundane.  It forsakes the grand gestures but leaves the formal tension.  Startlingly strong feeling bleeds through. <br /> <br />(Even the bullfight scenes, where Hemingway lets himself get a bit journalistic, come off as more color and feeling than event or spectacle.  Maybe all were one in Pamplona.)   <br /> <br />Is \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" his best book?  Maybe. \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" certainly beats it for scope and local color, and has the distinction of being one of the best war books ever written, and that's a category to care about.  But he never topped his first novel in its revolutionary honesty.  Read it when you're somewhat young, if you still have time.  It won't give you a hero to follow or words to live by, but art with this sort of integrity can nevertheless teach you how to live.  And that's heroic.
B00003ZKRM|5.0|Until late in his career, Barbirolli was overshadowed by Beecham, the greatest champion of Sibelius in Britain (perhaps the world). Their performances are very different, Beecham being more confident, extroverted, and showy in his approach, Barbirolli more moody, tender and personal. He was in general a personal musician, taking a long time to gather his thoughts about each score. Certain symphonies here, such as the 4th and 7th, come across with total conviciton--you feel and think along with the conductor.<br /><br />For many listeners, Barbirolli's Sibelius may now have risen above Beecham's for that reason--it's highly ocmmunicative. His pace is usually measured, and he emphasizes the atmospheric wind solos that flavor this music. Beecham had a superior orchestra in the Royal Phil., but the Halle was sensitive to Barbirolli's nuances of phrasing (we hear a lot of that in the mystical Fourth). The bigger, more popular works, such as the Second and Fifth Sym., can't hold their own for execution against versions from powerful, world-famous ensembles like the Berlin and NY Phil. led by powerhouse conductors like Bernstein and Karajan. But Barbriolli wasn't aiming for the grand effect, even in these works, so there's a special niche for his versions, too.<br /><br />Relegated to Pye, a secondary British label, Barbirolli did earlir versions of the First and Fift. These recordings, a complete cycle made just before his death, now rise to their rightful place on EMI. I'm giving five stars even though I am not enamored of Barbirolli's rough-hewn First (graced by some truly ugly playing), somewhat stodgy Third and underpowered Sixth, nor do I have a fondness for some of the routine incidental music that fills out the set. ('Finlandia' begins with the most grating brass chords I ever hope to hear.) But it's impossible to over-praise the best of these readings, especially a revelatory Fourth, and the sonics, dating from 1966-69, are generally fine.<br /><br />P.S. 2010 - Newcomers to this set shouldn't jump into its arms without making sure that they don't mind the mediocre playing from the Halle Orch., which does play a major factor for me. The beauties of Barbirolli's imagination (and Sibelius's) have to contend with some very unbeautiful sounds.uldn't jump into its arms without making sure that they don't mind the mediocre playing from the Halle Orch., which does play a major factor for me. The beauties of Barbirolli's imagination (and Sibelius's) have to contend with some very unbeautiful sounds.
B000AM6OQ2|4.0|Here is the lowdown on the re-release of this Special Edition.  The original S.E (Green cover art) was put out by MGM in late 2002 with the Hi-Def transfer, 5.1 audio, featurettes - all the bells and whistles.  When Sony acquired MGM in 2005, they discontinued this version. Taking the existing DLT, they slapped on a trailer for their new re-make (as well as the prerequisite umpteen cross-promotional trailers) and altered the cover art (Blue!) for no other reason than to drive ticket sales for what turned out to be one of the worst horror re-makes of this truly ugly cycle American cinema seems to be going through now. So unless you're hungry for advertising, go with whichever one you can find for the least amount of money - it's all the same thing.

Something to add in your children's bookshelf, and I say you wouldn't be disappointed.

Believe me the real history on which this is based is a lot more exciting than this book.

Riddick who is a prisoner being transported by a bounty hunter who also survived.  The planet is arid and bright under three suns. Seems like everyone will be able to get off the planet with a little work. <br /> <br />But then trouble begins when one of the survivors enters a dark place.  There is still life around but it clings to the dark.  Not a problem with the three suns.  Not until someone discovers that the suns are all about to be blocked by a giant planet.  Soon darkness falls and only the strength and determination of a convicted felon will be able to pull anyone through as they must finish the repairs while fending off the night predators. <br /> <br />According to some preview material when the movie was first released, Riddick is a government assassin who has outlived his mission but the government has been unable to eliminate him as he is too good.  This background gives one a different view of this movie.  The later additions to the series seem to have abandoned this idea.  Still, it is a good story of enlightened self interest. 0739326740|3.0|I put off reading this book until the hype got to me.  What's with the Christian culture and religious scandals?  I have to admit that the book is riveting, and got off to a fabulous start. After that, all the events seemed so contrived, all arranged just so, with perfect timing, to make everything come out right. A million things could have gone wrong for Langdon and Sophie if they were real life characters, but no, everything gets orchestrated beautifully, if improbably, by the author.<br /><br />Without spoiling the plot too much, consider the actions of Sauniere after he is shot in the stomach.  I've never been shot in the stomach, but I can't imagine a 70 year-old man doing anything more than curling up to die; but no, he spends the last 15-20 minutes of his life to create a most clever, devious, subtle set of clues for Langdon, to safeguard a secret that is so banal it is not worth losing one's life over.  How is he sure that Langdon will find the clues and draw the right conclusions?<br /><br />Just when you think Langdon and Sophie (another improbable character) have finally solved the puzzle, it turns out the solution is simply one more clue to another puzzle, which in turn must be solved.  Towards the end of the book, it gets a bit ridiculous.  The only thing that kept me going was the anticipation of a juicy secret that made all this effort worthwhile.<br /><br />So, what is this fantastic secret that a secret society kept under covers for centuries, for which people willingly gave up their lives, and for which real life people today get upset about?  Was Jesus a sexual deviant?  Was Jesus, in fact, an ancestor of Mohammed?  Did Jesus condemn his earlier teachings, including the Sermon on the Mount?  These would have been sensational enough, but still irrelevant in the context of Christian spirituality.  The real secret, which I won't give away, is so hopelessly trite that I simply can't imagine people getting worked up over it.  What am I missing?<br /><br />Does the alleged 'shameful past' invalidate Jesus' teachings?  Does it negate the Commandments?  Even if Jesus had been a sexual deviant (which historically he wasn't to the best of our knowledge, and the book certainly doesn't claim), why should that invalidate what he said?  The book's ending is a massive anticlimax. To this day I can't fathom why people get upset over the final revelation in the book.  It is so banal, almost like claiming Jesus did not floss everyday.  Big deal!<br /><br />The book's plot structure, pace, and sense of drama are excellent (if sometimes too tedious and painfully contrived).  But the ending is a total letdown. I felt that the author's talent (not to speak of my time) was wasted on a trivial, senseless issue.  A bit like Einstein using his genius to invent an onion slicer. I recommend the book, if only as an example of how an excellent work of fiction can be corrupted by a meaningless triviality.past' invalidate Jesus' teachings?  Does it negate the Commandments?
